questions.text:
A woman presents with insidious onset worsening exertional breathlessness and occasional exertional chest pain. On examination, she has increased JVP, peripheral edema, ascites, and a loud P2. Her investigations are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
  • Chest X-ray - enlarged central pulmonary arteries and vascular pruning 
  • Echocardiography - hypertrophied right ventricle
  • ECG - right ventricular hypertrophy

JVP: Jugulovenous pulse, STEMI: ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is pulmonary hypertension. 

Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is characterized by an elevation in pulmonary arterial pressures and increased vascular resistance caused by various causes. It is defined by mean pulmonary artery pressure (mPAP) > 20mmHg

Clinical features include dyspnea, edema, chest pain, and syncope. It is irreversible as it does not have a curative treatment and thus can lead to decompensated right heart failure and death. 

Clinical signs may include right heart failure features such as elevated JVP, edema, ascites as a result of disease progression. Chest auscultation may reveal loud P2, S3 and S4. 

Investigations of PH include: 

  • Echocardiogram with bubble study - it is an important screening test. It usually shows a dilated, hypertrophied right ventricle and increased pulmonary artery systolic pressure.
  • Right heart catheterization - it is the gold standard test to establish the diagnosis of PH and to select appropriate therapy.
  • Chest X-ray - may show obliteration of retrosternal space, enlarged pulmonary arteries, and peripheral vascular pruning.
  • ECG - right ventricular hypertrophy

Other options: 

Option A: Acute STEMI would reveal ST elevations in ECG. It is an acute event while this patient has had insidious onset exertional chest pain. Pain is classically described as heavy, squeezing, and crushing. Cardiac biomarkers are also raised in STEMI.

Option C: Left-sided heart failure is characterized by pulmonary edema, dyspnea, orthopnea, and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Elevated JVP, weight gain, gastrointestinal symptoms and ascites are signs of right-sided heart failure. 

Option D: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is the most common cause of sudden death in young individuals. It is characterized by exertional dyspnea, angina, left-sided congestion, and left-ventricular outflow obstruction.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient presented with breathlessness and fatigue for 5 months. Chest X-ray showed left atrial enlargement with straightening of the left cardiac border. Echocardiogram showed reduced opening of the mitral valve during diastole with thickening of the valve leaflets. Which among the following findings can be heard during auscultation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mitral stenosis (MS), and a mid-diastolic murmur can be heard during auscultation.

MS is a valvular heart disease, most commonly caused by rheumatic fever. Other causes include:

  • Congenital defects like cor triatriatum and parachute valve
  • Mitral annular calcification with leaflet involvement
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Left atrial myxoma
  • Infective endocarditis with large vegetations

Chronic inflammation causes thickening of the valve leaflets and shortening and fusion of chordae tendineae, leading to the formation of a funnel-shaped or fish-mouth valve. Calcification immobilizes the leaflets and narrows the valve further. Thrombi are also commonly formed from the calcified valve or dilated left atrium (in atrial fibrillation).

Patients present with dyspnea and cough in early stages of the condition. But as the disease progresses, daily acitivities are limited and the patient develops orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Hemoptysis can occur due to rupture of pulmonary-bronchial venous connections as a result of pulmonary venous hypertension.

Auscultatory findings of MS include:

  • Accentuated and slightly delayed first heart sound (S1)
  • Close splitting of the second heart sound (S2)
  • Accentuated pulmonic component of S2 (P2) when pulmonary artery pressure is elevated
  • Opening snap (OS) of the mitral valve following the aortic component of S2 (A2):
    • Audible during expiration at or just medial to the cardiac apex
  • Mid-diastolic murmur following OS:
    • Low pitched, rumbling
    • Heard best at the apex with the patient in the left lateral position
    • Accentuated by mild exercise
    • Duration of the murmur correlates with the severity of the stenosis
    • Reappears or becomes louder during atrial systole in patients with sinus rhythm (presystolic accentuation)
  • Soft systolic murmurs heard at or medial to the apex (signify mixed mitral valve disease with regurgitation)

When the cardiac output is severely reduced, the typical auscultatory findings may not be heard. This is known as silent MS. Hepatomegaly, pedal edema, ascites, and pleural effusion, may occur in patients with right ventricular failure.

Other associated murmurs include:

  • Pansystolic murmur of functional tricuspid regurgitation:
    • Occurs with severe pulmonary hypertension
    • Audible along the left sternal border
    • Louder during inspiration and reduces during forced expiration (Carvallo’s sign)
  • Graham Steell murmur of pulmonary regurgitation:
    • High-pitched, diastolic, decrescendo blowing murmur
    • Audible along the left sternal border
    • Occurs with severe pulmonary hypertension

Other options:

Option B:

An ejection mid-systolic murmur can be auscultated in aortic stenosis. It begins after S1, increases in intensity toward the middle of ejection, and ends just before aortic valve closure. It is low-pitched, rough, and rasping in character. It is best heard at the base of the heart, most commonly in the second right intercostal space.

A systolic ejection click can be heard in young patients with a bicuspid aortic valve, but disappears as the valves become calcified. A2 and P2 may be heard at the same time or A2 may follow P2, resulting in paradoxical splitting of S2. A fourth heart sound (S4) is often heard at the apex, indicating the presence of left ventricular hypertrophy.

Option C:

A pansystolic murmur of at least grade III/VI intensity can be auscultated in chronic severe mitral regurgitation. It is heard best at the apex and radiates to the axilla. Ruptured chordae tendineae may produce a murmur with a cooing or “seagull” quality, whereas a flail leaflet may produce a murmur with a musical quality. 

S1 is generally absent or soft. Wide splitting of S2 may occur due to premature closure of the aortic valve. A low-pitched third heart sound (S3) may occur following A2. S4 can also be audible in patients with acute severe MR.

Option D:

An early diastolic murmur can be auscultated in chronic aortic regurgitation. It is high-pitched and blowing in character. It is best heard in the third intercostal space along the left sternal edge. It may be accompanied by a mid-systolic ejection murmur in isolated AR or the Austin Flint murmur in severe AR. The latter is a soft, low-pitched, rumbling, mid-to-late diastolic murmur produced by the displacement of the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve by the AR stream.

A2 is usually absent and occasionally, S4 also may be heard.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with an ST-segment elevation?
questions.solution:
There is no ST-segment elevation in unstable angina.

Differential diagnosis of ST-segment elevation (Mnemonic-ELEVATION):

  • Electrolytes(Hypercalcemia, Hyperkalemia)
  • Left bundle branch block
  • Early(Benign) repolarization, Embolism(Acute pulmonary)
  • Ventricular hypertrophy
  • Arrhythmia(Brugada syndrome), Aneurysm of LV, Aortic dissection, Antiarrhythmic drugs(Class 1c)
  • Tako-tsubo syndrome, Tumor invading left ventricle, Trauma to ventricles
  • Infarction(MI), Inflammation(Myocarditis, Pericarditis)
  • Osborn J waves (Hypothermia or hypercalcemia)
  • Non-atherosclerotic vasospasm(Prinzmetal's angina)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient comes with complaints of progressive weakness that worsens in the evening. He is diagnosed with myasthenia gravis. Which of the following drug can exacerbate symptoms?
questions.solution:
Azithromycin can exacerbate the symptoms of myasthenia gravis (MG) by affecting presynaptic neuromuscular transmission. 

Many drugs are known to increase weakness in patients with MG, and hence must be avoided:

  • Antibiotics like aminoglycosides, quinolones, and macrolides (azithromycin)
  • Beta-blockers
  • Botulinum toxin
  • Local anaesthetics
  • Magnesium
  • Non–depolarising muscle relaxants
  • Penicillamine
  • Quinine derivatives

Preferred drug for diagnosis of MG: Edrophonium

Treatment for myasthenia gravis involves:

  • Symptomatic treatment: Anticholinesterase agents – pyridostigmine is the initial therapy of choice.
  • Chronic immunomodulating therapy: Glucocorticoids like prednisone and immunosuppressive drugs like azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, cyclosporine. These are used when patients are significantly symptomatic despite on pyridostigmine
  • Rapid immunomodulating treatment: IVIG and therapeutic plasma exchange. Thses are used to in severe illness like myasthenic crisis and as bridge therapy before surgery, or starting chronic immunomodulating treatment
  • Monoclonal antibodies: Rituximab is used in patients with MuSK antibody positive. Eculizumab is other monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of MG
  • Surgical approach: Thymectomy and surgical removal of thymoma.

Related Pearl: Auto antibodies in a few disorders

Auto-antibodies in myasthenia gravis:

i) Anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies

ii) Anti-muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies

iii) Anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4) antibodies

Anti-C1q antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and membrane proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). 

Anti-Smith antibodies (Anti-Sm) are associated with SLE.

Anti-lysosome associated membrane protein-2 (LAMP-2) antibodies are associated with certain types of vasculitis.

questions.text: A girl was brought by her parents with an itchy rash as shown in the image below. She also complains of difficulty in climbing stairs. A muscle biopsy reveals peri-fascicular atrophy. Immunohistochemistry revealed positive Myxovirus resistance protein A. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image of Gottron's papules along with the history suggestive of proximal muscle weakness and the investigation findings are suggestive of dermatomyositis.

Dermatomyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy. It is characterized by proximal skeletal muscle weakness, muscle inflammation, and a variety of characteristic skin manifestations.  

The classic cutaneous features in dermatomyositis include:

  • Gottron’s sign - erythematous to violaceous rash that occur symmetrically over the extensor (dorsal) aspects of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP)/ knuckle joints, elbows, knees, and ankles. Raised erythematous rash over the knuckles is pathognomic of dermatomyositis is called Gottron's papules.
  • Heliotrope rash - erythematous discoloration of eyelids with periorbital edema
  • Shawl sign- macular erythema of the upper chest and back
  • V sign - rash on the neck and chest in a V shaped manner due to sun exposure.
  • Poikiloderma - areas of hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation, atrophy and telangiectasia
  • Nail fold changes
  • Mechanic's hands
  • Cutaneous calcinosis

In dermatomyositis, skeletal muscle weakness involves proximal muscles in a symmetric manner and the muscle biopsy shows peri-fascicular atrophy. However, the Myxovirus resistance protein A immunohistochemistry test is more specific than biopsy. A highly raised creatinine kinase can help in diagnosis as well.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman presents with dry cough and mild fever for 5 days and musculoskeletal pain for one week. Examination reveals increased respiratory rate and skin lesions all over her body as shown below. Other findings are given below. What is the most effective drug for this condition?

Temperature: 37.8 degrees

Pulse rate: 98 bpm

Blood pressure: 100/70mmHg

Chest X-ray shows patchy consolidation

Bronchoalveolar lavage culture shows a fried egg appearance
questions.solution:
The given scenario point towards pneumonia whereas the constitutional symptoms, patchy consolidation on chest Xray and fried egg appearance on culture is suggestive of atypical pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae. Azithromycin is the most effective drug for the treatment of M. pneumonia.

Pneumonia due to M. pneumonia is also referred to as Eaton agent pneumonia, primary atypical pneumonia, and walking pneumonia. Other bacterial causes of atypical community-acquired pneumonia are Chlamydia pneumonia and Legionella.

Upper respiratory tract infection (tracheobronchitis/ pharyngitis) and pneumonia are common pulmonary manifestations. Majority of patients with Mycoplasma pneumonia present with dry cough, sore throat and fever.

It is also can present with extrapulmonary manifestations including erythema multiforme/Steven-Johnson syndrome (SJS), cold agglutinin disease, Guillain Barre syndrome, and transverse myelitis, arthritis, myocarditis, pericarditis and encephalitis.

Investigations include PCR of respiratory secretions and chest X-rays. Chest X-ray shows patchy consolidation with thickened bronchial markings and subsegmental atelectasis.

Culture shows a typical fried egg appearance (central opaque granular area of growth sorrounded by a flat translucent peripheral zone) on PPLO agar. The diagnosis is made by serology or by PCR. 

Azithromycin is the most effective drug for management. Other drugs used are doxycycline, clarithromycin, erythromycin, moxifloxacin, levofloxacin, gemifloxacin.

Other options:

Options A and B: Amoxicillin and Cefotaxime are beta-lactam antibiotics (cell-wall synthesis inhibitors), hence they are not effective on M.pneumoniae as they lack a cell wall.

Option D: Ciprofloxacin and ofloxacin are not recommended because of their high minimal inhibitory concentrations against M. pneumoniae isolates.

questions.text: The most common pattern of renal involvement in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is:
questions.solution:
Class IV lupus nephitis is the most frequent pattern of renal involvement in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

Lupus nephritis is one of the common serious complications seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). It occurs due to the deposition of circulating immune complexes of DNA and anti-DNA. This further activate the complement cascade and lead to complement-mediated damage.

Most common finding is proteinuria. Other features include hematuria, hypertension, varying degrees of renal failure. 

Laboratory findings include presence of anti-dsDNA antibodies and reduced complement levels. Red blood cell casts can be present on examination of urine sediment.

It is classified into 6 subtypes (classes) based on histological findings of the biopsy specimen taken from affected kidney. The most common histologic pattern is Class IV with diffuse lesions involving > 50% of all glomeruli.

Treatment is based on the histologic subtype of lupus nephritis:

  • Class I and II - lesions are limited to the renal mesangium. They need no therapy and have an excellent prognosis
  • Class III - characterized by focal nephritis. Mild proliferation involving a small percentage of glomeruli respond well to steroids.
  • Class IV - characterized by diffuse nephritis 
    • Initial therapy - high dose steroids, cyclophosphamide or mycophenolate 
    • Maintainance therapy - low dose steroids, mycophenolate or azathioprine
  • Renal failure due to lupus - renal transplantation is recommended after 6 months of disease inactivity

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought with complaints of hematuria and melena for 10 days. Laboratory investigations reveal mild thrombocytopenia and normal coagulation tests. Peripheral smear is given below. Which organism is most frequently involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing helmet cells or schistocytes are suggestive of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). This condition is most commonly associated with enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli strain O157: H7 worldwide.

This strain releases Shiga-like toxin. This toxin is absorbed from the inflamed gastrointestinal mucosa into the circulation and causes endothelial dysfunction. It leads to platelet activation and aggregation. Children and older adults are at the highest risk.

questions.text:
A consultant asks one of his patients to keep his fingers as shown in the image to elicit a clinical finding. Which of the following conditions are likely to cause an abnormal sign pertaining to this clinical finding?
  1. Irritable bowel syndrome
  2. Lung abscess
  3. Cystic fibrosis
  4. Aortic aneurysm
  5. Hemiplegia
questions.solution:
The consultant, by asking the patient to keep the dorsal surfaces of his fingers opposed (Schamroth sign), is trying to elicit clubbing. Clubbing is seen in conditions like lung abscess, cystic fibrosis, aortic aneurysm, and hemiplegia, but not in irritable bowel syndrome.

Digital clubbing is a focal bulbous enlargement of the terminal segments of the fingers and/or toes. It occurs due to the proliferation of connective tissue between the nail matrix and the distal phalanx. Clubbed fingers are also known as watch-glass nails, drumstick fingers, and Hippocratic fingers/nails.

Hypoxia causes increased release of platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). This leads to increased vascularity, permeability, and connective tissue changes.

The image below shows finger clubbing.

Clinical methods to elicit clubbing are:

  • Schamroth sign: It is performed by placing the dorsal surfaces of terminal phalanges of corresponding right and left fingers together. Normal fingers create a diamond-shaped window, but this window is obliterated in clubbed fingers. 
  • Lovibond's angle/Profile sign: It is the angle made by the nail as it exists from the proximal nail fold. Normally, this angle is usually less than 180°. In true clubbing, it is more than 180°.
  • Hyponychial angle: This is constructed by drawing a line from the distal digital crease to the cuticle and another line from the cuticle to hyponychium (the thickened stratum corneum of epidermis under the free edge of the nail). The normal angle is less than 192°.
  • Phalangeal depth ratio: This is defined by the ratio of the digit's depth measured at the nail bed and distal interphalangeal joint. Normally, the depth at the distal interphalangeal joint is more than that at the nail bed. A phalangeal depth ratio of more than 1 is indicative of clubbing.
  • Digital index: This is the sum of the phalangeal depth ratios for all 10 fingers. A digital index of 10.2 or more is indicative of clubbing. This is more specific for clubbing than the phalangeal depth ratio.

Causes of clubbing are:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Mesothelioma
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Diffuse pulmonary disease - pulmonary fibrosis, asbestosis
  • GI
    • Inflammatory bowel disease - ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Gastric and colonic carcinoma
    • Cirrhosis
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Infective endocarditis
    • Aortic aneurysm
    • Arteriovenous malformations
    • Atrial myxoma
  • Endocrine
    • Hyperthyroidism - Grave’s disease
  • CNS
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)

Clubbing may occur as isolated finding, but when it occurs along with subperiosteal new bone formation in the long bones and painful joint enlargement, it is known as the syndrome of hypertrophic osteoarthropathy. This is seen in conditions like bronchogenic carcinoma, mesothelioma, bronchiectasis, and hepatic cirrhosis.

Pseudoclubbing is asymmetrical involvement of the fingers. It is seen in conditions like chronic renal failure, subungal hemangioma, and systemic sclerosis. Radiologically, there is acro-osteolysis (resorption of the terminal tufts) due to soft-tissue collapse.

questions.text: A man presented with fatigue and a mass in the left upper abdomen. On examination, there was massive splenomegaly with no lymphadenopathy. Investigations revealed pancytopenia. His peripheral blood smear is given below. Immunohistochemistry revealed tumor cells to be positive for annexin A1, CD22, CD25, and CD103. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image shows hairy cells i.e. abnormal B cells having round nuclei and pale blue cytoplasm with thread-like extensions. So the likely diagnosis is hairy cell leukemia. 

Hairy cell leukaemia is a rare type of B-cell tumour involving small lymphocytes. The specific activating point mutation is in the serine/ threonine kinase BRAFV600E.

Symptoms occur due to infiltration of bone marrow, liver and spleen. Clinical features include:

  • Massive splenomegaly and hepatomegaly. Lymphadenopathy is rare
  • Pancytopenia - due to marrow involvement can also be seen
  • Monocytopenia - leads to increased incidence of atypical mycobacterial infections

Routine peripheral smear shows hairy cells (abnormal B cells) having round, oblong or reniform nuclei and pale blue cytoplasm with thread-like extensions as shown below. 

Hairy cell leukaemia is limited to the red pulp of the spleen which is heavily infiltrated. This leads to obliteration of white pulp and a beefy red gross appearance. 

The pattern of bone marrow involvement on biopsy specimens is pathognomonic for hairy cell leukemia.

  • Diffuse infiltration of tumor cells with honeycomb appearance
  • Individual cells have a fried egg appearance i.e. the nucleus of each hairy cell is surrounded by a halo of cytoplasm
  • Dry tap is obtained upon performing bone marrow aspiration due to marrow fibrosis and the interlocking cell borders of hairy cells

The image given below shows small cells with clear cytoplasm and a round central nucleus ("fried egg"-like appearance).

Tests for hairy cell leukemia include:

  • CD11c, CD25 and CD103 are the characteristic immunophenotype diagnostic markers
  • Pan-B markers such as CD19, CD20, and CD22 also test positive 
  • Annexin A1 on bone marrow specimens have been shown to have 100% sensitivity and specificity in differentiating hairy cell leukemia from other B cell malignancies.
  • Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) stain is an important tool in the clinical diagnosis of hairy cell leukemia and yields positive results in  majority of the cases.

Management of hairy cell leukemia include:

  • Splenectomy
  • Cladribine (first line agent) and deoxycoformycin are highly active nucleoside agents that cause durable remissions in patients.

Other options:

Option A: Primary myelofibrosis is the replacement of the marrow by fibrous tissue leading to reduced bone marrow haematopoiesis. This results in cytopenia, and extramedullary haematopoiesis (in the spleen mainly). The peripheral blood smear shows tear drop-shaped red cells (dacrocytes).

Option C: Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell tumor. Patients present with lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, renal failure, and acquired immune abnormalities. Plasma cell tumors are positive for CD138, syndecan-1 (adhesion molecule), and CD56. Bone-marrow biopsy shows mott cells (a variant of plasma cell) with globular inclusions called Russell bodies (if cytoplasmic) or Dutcher bodies (if nuclear).

Option D: Mantle cell lymphomas express high levels of cyclin D1, CD19, and CD20. The tumor is usually CD5+ and CD23−. Painless lymphadenopathy is the most common presentation. Other organs involved are spleen and gut.

A postgraduate student, while assisting an emergency trauma surgery on an HIV-infected patient, has suffered a bleeding puncture wound in his right index finger. The post-exposure prophylaxis is given for 4 weeks. Match the drug with their daily dosages?

questions.solution:
Recommended post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is a three drug regimen which includes lamivudine 300mg , tenofovir 300mg and dolutegravir 50mg. The PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours.

Most common cause of HIV in a healthcare worker is due to needle stick injuries. Exposure to needle stick injuries can be prevented by:

  • Careful handling and disposing of sharps and needles after use.

questions.text: A man presents with headache, fever, and neck stiffness for the last 1 month. On examination, the sign shown in the image below is positive. CSF analysis reveals lymphocytic predominance with low glucose levels. A cobweb coagulum is formed when CSF is left standing. What is the therapy of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The scenario of a positive Kernig's sign, as shown in the image, and CSF analysis findings of lymphocytic predominance with low glucose level and cobweb formation suggest tubercular meningitis. The therapy of choice for this patient is isoniazid + rifampin + pyrazinamide+ ethambutol. 

Kernig's sign is elicited with the patient in supine position. The thigh and knee are flexed over the abdomen. The examiner then tries to passively extend the knee joint. There is severe pain during extension due to meningeal irritation.

Tubercular meningitis is a type of subacute meningitis. It is caused due to the hematogenous dissemination of the bacilli into the brain parenchyma. These bacilli form tubercles. The tubercles undergo caseating necrosis and release the tubercular antigens in the subarachnoid space, leading to inflammation of the meninges. They predominantly involve the basal portion of the brain.

Symptoms include headache, neck stiffness, features of cranial nerve palsies such as facial weakness, downward and outward positioning of the eyes, diminished vision, double vision, and hearing loss. Signs include papilledema, Kernig's sign, and Brudzinki's sign of meningeal irritation.

It is treated with fixed-dose combinations of isoniazid (5 mg/kg/d), rifampin (10 mg/kg/d), pyrazinamide (30 mg/kg/d), ethambutol (15 mg/kg/d), and pyridoxine (50 mg/d) for a period of 6 months. It can be extended by 3-6 months in cases of tubercular meningitis. Also, in HIV-negative patients with TB meningitis, dexamethasone (12–16 mg/d) is recommended for 6 weeks. In India, tuberculosis is managed with a fixed-dose combination and daily dosing of medications.

Other options:

Option B: Ceftriaxone + vancomycin is the initial treatment of choice for acute meningitis due to Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Option C: Ampicillin is the treatment of choice for meningitis due to Listeria monocytogenes and is given for at least 3 weeks.

Option D: Liposomal amphotericin B + flucytosine is used for chronic meningitis due to Cryptococcus neoformans (in patients with no immunosuppression).

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease of symmetric polyarthritis, mainly affecting the small joints of the hands and feet. The wrists and metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints are most frequently involved. Being a systemic disease, RA also causes various extraarticular manifestations, like subcutaneous nodules, lung involvement, pericarditis, peripheral neuropathy, vasculitis, and hematologic abnormalities. Testing for serum antibodies to anti-citrullinated protein antibodies and rheumatoid factor can help in the quick diagnosis and management of suspected RA.

Osteoarthritis (OA) is the most common type of arthritis, mainly affecting the hip, knee, and first metatarsal phalangeal, first carpometacarpal, and distal and proximal interphalangeal joints. The incidence of OA is very high in the elderly and more common in women. It is diagnosed based on structural abnormalities, like cartilage loss (seen as joint space loss on X-ray) and osteophytes, which occur due to failure of joint protective mechanisms.

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease characterized by autoantibody- and immune complex-mediated tissue destruction. It is a multisystem disease, resulting in musculoskeletal, cutaneous, renal, hematologic, cardiopulmonary, and neurologic symptoms and signs. Diagnostically, the most important autoantibodies are antinuclear antibodies because they are positive in >95% of patients.

Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory type of arthritis mainly affecting the distal interphalangeal joints. In most cases, psoriasis precedes arthritis. Other features include nail changes (pitting, horizontal ridging, onycholysis, yellowish discoloration, hyperkeratosis), dactylitis, enthesitis, and tenosynovitis. The Classification of Psoriatic Arthritis (CASPAR) criteria are a useful tool for early diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: A woman with hysteria who was hyperventilating developed carpo-pedal spasm. What could be the likely cause for this?
questions.solution:
Respiratory alkalosis, developed secondary to hyperventilation, is the likely cause of the carpopedal spasm.

Hyperventilation leads to the washout of carbon dioxide, resulting in decreased levels of PaCO2 (hypocapnia), which in turn increases the pH (alkalosis). Thus, acute respiratory alkalosis occurs during hyperventilation. An increase in extracellular pH increases the binding of free calcium to albumin, lowering the ionized calcium concentration. This leads to hypocalcemia.

The clinical features of hypocalcemia are:

  • Tetany: Increased peripheral neuromuscular irritability. May include perioral paresthesias, muscle spasms, and cramps.
  • Trosseau's sign: Induction of carpal spasm when the BP cuff is inflated 20 mm Hg over the systolic BP for three minutes or more.
  • Chvostek's sign: Contraction of the ipsilateral circumoral facial muscles when the facial nerve is tapped just anterior to the ear.
  • Severe hypocalcemia can cause seizures, carpopedal spasm, bronchospasm, and laryngospasm.

Treatment of the underlying condition is necessary. The patient should be reassured and rebreathing from a paper bag should be done during acute episodes.

questions.text: A male patient with complaints of jaundice and pruritis shows elevated GGT and ALP.  ERCP revealed beading in both intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree. A biopsy was done and showed concentric onion ring fibrosis. The autoantibody most likely to be positive in this condition is:
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and biopsy findings of onion ring fibrosis are suggestive of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). The autoantibody most likely to be positive in this condition is p-ANCA. 

The auto antibodies in the decreasing order of positivity in PSC are p-ANCA>ANA>AMA.

PSC is the diffuse inflammation and fibrosis of the entire biliary tree (intrahepatic and extrahepatic). It results in chronic cholestasis, cirrhosis, portal hypertension and finally liver failure.

Clinical features include cholestatic jaundice, pruritis, steatorrhea, fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies, and fatigue.

Liver function tests show a cholestatic pattern with an elevation of ALP and GGT and smaller rises in the aminotransferases. Bilirubin values can be variable. Majority of patients with PSC are positive for perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (pANCA).

Definitive diagnosis is by cholangiographic imaging showing multiple dilatations and strictures (beading) of both intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) is the imaging of choice, cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is done if MRCP is nondiagnostic.

Currently, there is no known curative treatment. Surgical management involves biliary stenting or endoscopic dilatation of strictures. For patients with advanced liver disease, liver transplantation is the only available option for treatment.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with the following deformity. She complains of joint pain and stiffness in the fingers for 5-6 years. She reports that stiffness is more in the early morning and improves on performing household activities. What is the most common extra-articular manifestation seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with image showing swan neck deformity (hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint) is classically seen in rheumatoid arthritis. The most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis is subcutaneous nodules. 

Subcutaneous nodules are generally firm, non-tender nodules that are adherent to the periosteum, tendons, or bursae. They develop in areas that are subjected to repeated trauma or irritation such as the forearm, sacral prominences, and Achilles tendon. Nodules can also develop in the lungs, pleura, pericardium, and peritoneum. Infection, gangrene and malignant transformation can be rarely seen with subcutaneous nodules.

Other extraarticular manifestations seen in rheumatoid arthritis are:

  • Sjogren syndrome - it presents with keratoconjunctivitis sicca or xerostomia
  • Rheumatoid vasculitis - it presents as petechiae, purpura, digital infarcts, gangrene, livedo reticularis
  • Pulmonary -  
    • Pleuritis - most common pulmonary manifestation
    • Interstitial lung diseases
  • Cardiac - 
    • Pericarditis - most common cardiac manifestation
    • Cardiomyopathy
    • Mitral regurgitation
    • Coronary artery disease
  • Hematologic - 
    • Normochromic normocytic anemia - most common hematologic abnormality 
    • Felty's syndrome - is a triad of neutropenia, splenomegaly, and nodular rheumatoid arthritis. It is a rare manifestation
    • Lymphoma

Patients developing extra-articular manifestations are associated with risk factors such as: History of smoking, early onset of physical disability, rheumatoid factor positive and anti-CCP antibody positive.

questions.text: An 81-year-old woman presented with gradually increasing shortness of breath over the past 6 months. Examination reveals finger clubbing and bibasilar fine inspiratory crackles. Pulmonary function test showed a restrictive defect with reduced lung volumes. HRCT is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Respiratory bronchiolitis associated interstitial lung disease

questions.solution:
In a patient with chronic shortness of breath, finger clubbing, and fine inspiratory crackles, spirometry showing a restrictive defect and reduced lung volumes points to a diagnosis of interstitial lung disease. In the given HRCT, there is prominent honeycombing in the lower and posterior lung zones. This is seen in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).

Interstitial lung diseases are characterized by inflammation and fibrosis involving the lung parenchyma. Although there are multiple diseases under this subset, the clinical presentation for all of them is the same. The patients are usually over 60 years of age and present with progressive exertional dyspnea and dry cough. On examination, fine inspiratory, velcro crackles may be heard. Digital clubbing and cyanosis are signs of advanced disease.

Pulmonary function tests (PFT) will show a restrictive deficit and reduction of TLC, FEV1, and FVC. There is also a reduction in DLCO and may be the first finding seen in PFT. Other laboratory tests should be undertaken if the patient has symptoms involving other systems, to rule out any connective tissue disorder which might have led to ILD.

IPF is the most common interstitial lung disease occurring due to an unknown cause. HRCT shows predominant subpleural and basal involvement, in the form of reticulation, honeycombing, and traction bronchiectasis. This is known as the usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern. Note that ground glass opacities are absent in this pattern. 

The treatment of IPF is with antifibrotic therapy such as pirfenidone and nintedanib.

Other options:

Option A: Acute interstitial pneumonia is characterized by a sudden onset of hypoxemia and respiratory distress, following symptoms of an upper respiratory tract infection. HRCT shows patchy bilateral ground-glass opacities and consolidation of the air spaces.

Options B and D: Respiratory bronchiolitis associated with ILD (RB-ILD) and desquamative interstitial pneumonia (DIP) are more commonly seen in smokers. HRCT shows prominent ground-glass opacities in both these disorders.

questions.text:
A young woman complains of burning sensation during micturition, increased urinary frequency, and urgency. She does not complain of fever, flank pain, or colicky abdominal pain. Which of the following is/are the first-line medications used in this condition?
  1. Nitrofurantoin
  2. Ampicillin
  3. Trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole
  4. Ciprofloxacin
  5. Cephalosporins
questions.solution:
The given clinical sceanrio is suggestive of uncomplicated urinary tract infection (UTI), and nitrofurantoin and trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole are the first-line drugs used in this condition.

UTI encompasses many clinical entities, including asymptomatic bacteriuria, cystitis, prostatitis, and pyelonephritis. When the infection is confined to the bladder, also known as acute cystitis (the most common manifestation), it is known as uncomplicated UTI. This is more prevalent among women than men. When the infection extends beyond the bladder, causing systemic symptoms and signs, it is known as complicated UTI.

Frequent sexual intercourse, a history of UTI, diabetes, and incontinence are some of the important risk factors of UTI. It is most commonly caused by E. coli. Other species include Staphylococcus saprophyticus, Klebsiella, Proteus, Enterococcus, and Citrobacter species. 

Patients with cystitis typically present with dysuria, urinary frequency, and urgency. Nocturia, hesitancy, suprapubic discomfort, and gross hematuria can also be seen. Fever with a typical high spiking picket-fence pattern and rigors, flank and/or loin pain, nausea, and vomiting are seen in pyelonephritis. UTI can be complicated by the presence of infection, stones or foreign bodies, or delayed response to treatment.

Treatment in a patient with uncomplicated cystitis is started based on history alone. However, if symptoms are not specific or history is not reliable, a urine dipstick test is performed. Emperical treatment can be started in a woman with one symptom of UTI and a positive nitrite or leukocyte esterase result. In case of a negative result, urine culture and pelvic examination are recommended.

Antibiotic therapy include:

  • Trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SFX) and nitrofurantoin: These are the first-line drugs for uncomplicated cystitis. However, TMP-SFX show high rates of resistance and adversely affect the normal flora in the body. Pivmecillinam, fosfomycin, and nitrofurantoin can be used instead. 
  • Beta-lactam antibiotics: These are the second-line agents due to high rates of relapse and lower pathogen clearance.
  • Fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin): These are used for uncomplicated cystitis only if no other alternatives are available due to high rates of resistance and side effects like increased risk of Achilles tendon rupture and irreversible neuropathy. However, they are the first-line drugs for pyelonephritis.
  • Ampicillin and cephalosporins: These are drugs of choice in pregnancy.

questions.text: The ascitic fluid analysis of a patient shows SAAG >1.1 g/dL and ascitic protein <2.5 g/dL. The most likely etiology of ascites in this patient is
questions.solution:
In the given patient, serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) >1.1 g/dl and ascitic protein <2.5 g/dl. So the most likely etiology of ascities in this patient is cirrhosis.

Ascitic fluid is extracted percutaneously from the peritoneum of a patient, by means of a procedure called as paracentesis. This fluid must be examined for total protien levels, albumin levels, cell counts and differential counts. A serum albumin level should be measured simultaneously for calculating SAAG.

Related Pearl: Serum Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG)

The serum ascites albumin gradient is calculated as follows:

SAAG = Serum albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin

It can be used to determine the cause of ascites following ascitic fluid analysis.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male patient came with back pain and stiffness. He was found to have sacroiliitis on imaging and was diagnosed with ankylosing spondylitis. He is positive for an HLA marker. This marker positivity is also seen in _____.
  1. Psoriatic spondylitis
  2. Reactive arthritis due to Shigella
  3. Rheumatoid arthritis
  4. Behcet’s disease
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario of ankylosing spondylitis (AS), there will be positivity for HLA-B27. This marker positivity is also seen in psoriatic spondylitis (1) and reactive arthritis (2) due to Shigella.

HLA-B27 is also found to be positive in the following conditions:

  • Psoriatic spondylitis: Some patients with psoriatic arthritis have axial joint involvement without peripheral involvement, which presents similarly to AS.
  • Reactive arthritis: Acute non-purulent arthritis occurs a few days after a systemic infection or an infection elsewhere in the body. It is usually seen following enteric or urogenital infection. Organisms causing these infections are Shigella, Salmonella, Yersinia, and Chlamydia.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joint. It is more common in young males and strongly associates with HLA-B27.

Clinically, patients present with recurring backache, which worsens in the early morning or with inactivity and improves with exercise. Later, they develop fatigue, pain, joint swellings, and heel pain.

Extra-articular manifestations include uveitis, aortic incompetence, carditis, and apical lobe fibrosis.

X-ray findings:

  • Erosion of sacroiliac joints - sacroiliitis
  • Squaring of vertebrae and bamboo spine appearance

Other options:

  • Behcet's disease - HLA-B51 positive
  • Rheumatoid arthritis - HLA DR4 positive

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient came to the emergency room stating that she passed blood instead of urine. Labs revealed Hb 6.5 g/dL, leukocyte count 3500/mm3, platelet count 65000/mm3, reticulocytosis, and elevated LDH levels. Flow cytometry showed CD55- and CD59-negative RBCs. Which of the following drugs is used for the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), and the drug used to treat this condition is Eculizumab.

PNH is an acquired chronic hemolytic anaemia characterized by a triad of intravascular hemolysis, pancytopenia, and the tendency for venous thrombosis. 

Clinical features include:

  • Symptoms of anaemia (may also be discovered incidentally)
  • Increased susceptibility to infections (due to severe neutropenia)
  • Hemorrhage (due to severe thrombocytopenia)
  • Recurrent attacks of severe abdominal pain (due to abdominal vein thrombosis or intravascular hemolysis)
  • Budd-Chiari syndrome, presenting as acute hepatomegaly and ascites (due to hepatic vein thrombosis)

Lab investigations reveal:

  • Anaemia: Normo-macrocytic; can become microcytic due to chronic iron loss
  • Hemoglobinuria: Resulting in chronic iron loss
  • High MCV: May occur due to marked reticulocytosis 
  • Elevated unconjugated bilirubin
  • Markedly elevated LDH
  • Cellular bone marrow with marked erythroid hyperplasia, progressing to a hypocellular or aplastic bone marrow
  • Increased susceptibility of RBCs to complement (C): Occurs due to deficiency of surface proteins CD59 and CD55. This definitive diagnosis is performed via flow cytometry (high sensitivity). A bimodal distribution of cells is seen, with a substantial population of CD59- and CD55-negative cells.

Treatment involves anti-complement therapy with drugs such as eculizumab (administered IV every 2 weeks) and ravulizumab (administered every 8 weeks). 

However, since these drugs are expensive, supportive treatment is exceedingly important:

  • Folic acid supplements (at least 3 mg/d)
  • Periodic monitoring of serum iron, iron supplements, and blood transfusions whenever necessary
  • Regular anticoagulant prophylaxis for patients with venous thrombosis or thrombophilia
  • Thrombolytic treatment with tissue plasminogen activator for patients with thrombotic complications

Bone marrow transplant or immunosuppressive therapy should be considered in very young patients with severe PNH and possible bone marrow failure.

Other options:

Option B: Ocrelizumab is an anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody used to treat patients with relapsing and primary progressive multiple sclerosis. It depletes circulating B cells through antibody- and complement-dependent cytotoxicity.

Option C: Tocilizumab is an anti-IL-6 monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of giant cell arteritis, rheumatoid arthritis, cytokine release syndrome, COVID-19 infection, and systemic sclerosis.

Option D: Durvalumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor of the programmed death-ligand 1 pathway used to treat patients with stage III non-small cell lung carcinoma and limited-stage small cell lung carcinoma.

questions.text:
Which of the following disorders of bilirubin metabolism leads to predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia?
  1. Dubin-Johnson syndrome
  2. Gilbert syndrome
  3. Rotor syndrome
  4. Byler disease
questions.solution:
Dubin-Johnson syndrome, Rotor syndrome, and Byler disease are the disorders of bilirubin metabolism which lead to predominant conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia: It occurs either due to a hemolytic process producing excess bilirubin or due to a impaired uptake/ conjugation of bilirubin causing inadequate conjugation.

Causes of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia include: 

  • Increased bilirubin production due to hemolysis
    • Inherited - sickle cell anemia, thalassemia, G6PD deficiency
    • Acquired - paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
  • Increased bilirubin due to ineffective erythropoiesis
    • Iron, cobalamine, and folate deficiency
  • Drugs - Rifampicin, probenecid.
  • Hereditary defects in conjugation - 
    • Criggler-Najjar syndrome (type I and II)
    • Gilbert syndrome

Mixed or predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia: It occurs either due to impaired excretion of conjugated bilirubin into the bile ductules or due to backward leakage of the bile. 

Familial defects in hepatic excretory function include:

  • Dubin-Johnson syndrome
  • Rotor syndrome
  • Benign recurrent intrahepatic cholestasis (BRIC)

MCKD1 is due to a defect in the mucin 1 (MUC1) gene. The mutated gene codes for a large protein fragment that has a toxic effect on the tubules. It is not associated with elevated uric acid levels and gout.

MCKD2 is due to a defect in the UMOD gene, which codes for the protein uromodulin. It is associated with hyperuricemia and gout.

questions.text: A postpartum woman developed a severe headache and lactational failure. MRI revealed enlarged pituitary with a hemorrhagic infarct. She does not have any visual disturbance, ophthalmoplegia, or impaired consciousness. What is the most-likely management in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and MRI findings is suggestive of pituitary apoplexy in a post-partum woman. Since there is no evidence of visual loss or impaired consciousness, the most likely management in this case would be high-dose glucocorticoids.

Pituitary apoplexy is damage to the pituitary gland and the surrounding structures as a result of acute intrapituitary hemorrhagic vascular events. It occurs spontaneously, as in pre-existing adenoma or in postpartum cases (Sheehan's syndrome) or in association with other systemic diseases like diabetes mellitus, systemic hypertension, sickle cell anemia, and acute shock. 

Postpartum apoplexy is due to the hyperplastic enlargement of the pituitary gland (occuring normally in pregnant woman), which poses an increased risk for haemorrhage. Clinical features include:

  • Headache with signs of meningeal irritation
  • Lactational failure
  • Bilateral visual changes
  • Ophthalmoplegia
  • Cardiovascular collapse (shock) 
  • Hypoglycemia or diabetes mellitus
  • Loss of consciousness

Investigation of choice: MRI or CT shows signs of intratumoral or sellar hemorrhage, with pituitary stalk deviation and compression of pituitary tissue.

Treatment :

  • No signs of visual disturbances or loss of consciousness - high dose glucocorticoids
  • Signs of progressive visual loss, cranial nerve palsy, or loss of consciousness present - urgent surgical decompression

Note: Hypopituitarism follows pituitary apoplexy.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old female patient has hyperparathyroidism, pituitary adenoma, and gastrinoma with cutaneous angiofibromas. What is the likely diagnosis?

MEN - Multiple endocrine neoplasia
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of MEN 1 syndrome.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndromes are characterized by tumors of two or more endocrine glands. There are four major types of MEN (MEN 1–4), and they either show an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance or occur sporadically. 

MEN 1, also known as Wermer’s syndrome, is characterized by the triad of parathyroid, pancreatic islet cell, and anterior pituitary tumors. Adrenal cortical tumors, carcinoid tumors, facial angiofibromas, collagenomas, thyroid tumors, and lipomas may also occur. MEN 1-associated tumors are usually multiple, larger, and more aggressive, resulting in resistance to treatment and poor patient outcomes.

  1. Parathyroid tumors- primary hyperparathyroidism is the most common feature of MEN 1. Hypercalcemia with or without symptoms (polyuria, polydipsia, constipation, dyspepsia), nephrolithiasis, and osteitis fibrosa cystica may also occur. All four parathyroid glands are usually affected with multiple adenomas or hyperplasia. 
  2. Pancreatic islet cell tumors- these are neuroendocrine tumors, including:
    • Gastrinoma (gastrin-secreting tumors)- associated with increased gastric acid secretion and multiple peptic ulcers (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome). Patients may present with diarrhea and steatorrhea. Gastrinomas are the major cause of mortality and morbidity. 
    • Insulinoma (insulin-secreting tumors)- patients present with hypoglycemic symptoms (weakness, headaches, sweating, seizures, weight gain) that develop after fasting or exertion and improve after glucose intake. Along with increased plasma insulin levels and hypoglycemia, increased C peptide and proinsulin levels help in diagnosing the condition.
    • Glucagonoma (glucagon-secreting tumors)- may be associated with necrolytic migratory erythema, weight loss, anemia, and stomatitis. 
    • VIPomas (Vasoactive intestinal peptide [VIP]-secreting tumors): The VIPoma syndrome, also known as Verner-Morrison syndrome, is characterized by watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria. These are mostly located in the tail of the pancreas.
    • PPomas (Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting tumors) and nonfunctioning pancreatic tumors- are associated with a worse prognosis as they often go undiagnosed due to the absence of both clinical features and biochemical abnormalities.
  3. Pituitary tumors- manifestations depend on the hormone secreted (symptoms of hyperprolactinemia, acromegaly, or Cushing’s disease) and tumor size (visual disturbances or hypopituitarism due to compression of the optic chiasm or normal pituitary tissue). 

Surgical excision of the nonmetastatic tumor after localization is the curative treatment. Appropriate medical therapy can be used for some tumors when surgery is contraindicated or unsuccessful (calcimemetics for parathyroid tumors, parietal cell H+-K+-ATPase inhibitors for gastrinomas). In case of metastasis, chemotherapy, hormonal therapy, radiation therapy, and artery embolization may be successful.

MEN 1 occurs due to a mutation in the MEN1 gene located on chromosome 11q13. Mutational genetic analysis is necessary to confirm the clinical diagnosis and identify family members who harbor the mutation and require screening for tumor detection and early treatment.

Other options:

Options B and C: MEN 2, also called Sipple’s syndrome, is characterized by medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), pheochromocytomas, and parathyroid tumors. This occurs due to mutations of the rearranged during transfection (RET) protooncogene. There are three clinical variants -

  1. MEN 2A (most common): MTC is associated with pheochromocytomas in 50% of patients and parathyroid tumors in 20% of patients. MEN 2A may also be associated with Hirschsprung’s disease and cutaneous lichen amyloidosis.
  2. MEN 2B (MEN 3): MTC is associated with pheochromocytoma, along with Marfanoid habitus; mucosal neuromas of the lips, tongue, and eyelids; medullated corneal fibers; and intestinal autonomic ganglion dysfunction leading to multiple diverticulae and megacolon. Parathyroid tumors are usually absent.
  3. MTC only (FMTC): MTC is the only manifestation.

Option D: MEN 4 is characterized by a combination of MEN 1–associated tumors and CDKN1B mutation-related tumors (gonadal, adrenal, renal, and thyroid tumors).

questions.text:
A elderly hypertensive man presented with unilateral weakness of upper limbs and slurring of speech. NCCT scan was done to reveal the following sign. What is the name of the sign?

NCCT - Non-contrast computed tomography
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of unilateral weakness of upper limbs and slurring of speech in a hypertensive man is suggestive of stroke. The NCCT image is showing hyperdense MCA sign i.e. occlusion of middle cerebral artery (MCA) due to a hyperdense embolus. This sign is indicative of ischemic stroke. 

After the clinical diagnosis of stroke is made, an emergency evaluation should be made to check patient’s airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs), hypoglycemia/ hyperglycemia. The main goal is to distinguish it as either an ischemic stroke or hemorrhagic stroke with the help of an emergency noncontrast head CT. 

The following signs of acute ischemia can be seen on CT:

  • Blurring of the gray/white junction and effacement of the sulci due to ischemic swelling of the tissues.
  • Blurring of the margins of the gray matter structures
  • In cases of internal carotid artery occlusion or middle cerebral artery main segment (M1) occlusion, intraluminal clot may be seen as a focal hyperdensity, known as the hyperdense MCA sign or hyperdense dot sign.

Management includes:

  • Reduction of blood pressure when: BP >220/120 mmHg, presence of malignant hypertension or concomitant myocardial ischemia, or if blood pressure is >185/110 mmHg in a patient planned for intravenous thrombolysis.
  • Serum glucose maintained between 60 mg/dL and 180 mg/dL.
  • IV mannitol and water restriction may be required to reduce edema which can lead to a mass effect.
  • Intravenous thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rTPA), alteplase (0.9 mg/kg), tenecteplase (0.25 mg/kg) should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period (within 4.5 hours of symptom onset).
  • Endovascular mechanical thrombectomy is done in patients who not respond to thrombolytic therapy or in whom thrombolysis is contraindicated.
  • Oral aspirin with an initial dose of 300 mg should be started within 48 hours of acute ischemic stroke.

Other options:

Option A: String sign of Kantor is seen in Crohn's disease. It refers to the string like appearance of a contrast filled bowel loop due to luminal narrowing.

Option B: Eye of tiger sign is seen due to T2 hypointensity in the globus pallidus with a longitudinal stripe of high intensity. It is commonly seen in pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN) but is not pathognomic of the condition. It can be seen in Wilson's disease, atypical parkinsonism and organophosphate poisoning.

Option D: The dural tail sign is seen in meningioma due to thickening and enhancement of dura.

questions.text: A young man with a history of a respiratory tract infection 4 weeks ago, is unable to stand or walk for the past 2 weeks. His weakness began in the toes and ankles and progressed to involve his knee and hip joints. His upper limbs are not affected and cranial nerves are intact. On examination, there is an absent knee jerk. Which of the following would you consider as the initial therapy?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario depicting progressive, ascending, symmetrical weakness following a respiratory infection is suggestive of Guillain Barre syndrome (GBS). Intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) would be considered as the initial therapy in this patient.

GBS is an acute, fulminant polyradiculoneuropathy that is autoimmune in nature. Most of the cases occur after a respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. GBS is caused when immune response/antibodies are produced against external antigens like infections (Campylobacter jejuni, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, HHV) and vaccines (Influenza). These autoantibodies target similar proteins present in the person's nervous tissue (called molecular mimicry).

GBS manifests as a rapidly evolving motor paralysis with areflexia (or hyporeflexia) with or without sensory disturbance. It is an ascending paralysis that affects the lower limbs more than the upper limbs. It can also affect the cranial nerves leading the bulbar paralysis like difficulty articulating words and excessive drooling.

igh-dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis are equally effective for typical GBS. IVIg is the initial therapy chosen because of its ease of administration and good safety record. It contains anti-idiotypic antibodies against autoantibodies. It is administered as five daily infusions for a total dose of 2 g/kg body weight.

Other options: 

Option B - Mechanical ventilation is reserved for those who develop respiratory insufficiency or patients who develop early bulbar weakness. This patient has no bulbar weakness (normal cranial nerves).

Option C - Corticosteroid administration has not been shown to provide many benefits in GBS. 

Option D - Antibiotic administration would not be useful in GBS as the pathophysiology involves axonal degeneration due to a immune cause, not infective. 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of Immunopathogenesis of Guillain-Barre Syndrome

The following sequence of events, takes into consideration, the development of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

  1. B cells recognize glycoconjugates on jejuni (Cj) that cross-react with ganglioside present on Schwann cell surface and subjacent peripheral nerve myelin.
  2. Most of the B cells are activated via a partially T cell–dependent route and secrete primarily IgG autoantibodies. Some B cells, activated via a T cell–independent mechanism, secrete primarily IgM
  3. The activated B cells escape from Peyer’s patches into regional lymph nodes.
  4. Activated T cells also function to assist in the opening of the blood-nerve barrier, facilitating penetration of pathogenic autoantibodies.
  5. The earliest changes in myelin consist of edema between myelin lamellae and vesicular disruption of the outermost myelin layers.
  6. These effects are associated with activation of the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex and mediated by calcium entry; it is possible that the macrophage cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF) also participates in myelin damage.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented with pain and swelling of his right knee for one week. It started progressing to the ankle joints and feet for the past 2 days. questions.solution:
The given scenario of acute arthritis following a recent infection and additive pattern (involvement of new joints within few days) and examination finding of keratoderma blennorrhagica (image) are suggestive of reactive arthritis. 

Keratoderma blennorrhagica is a mucocutaneous manifestation of reactive arthritis. It presents as vesicles and pustules that lead to hyperkeratotic lesions or crusting on the palms and soles.

Other mucocutaneous manifestations of reactive arthritis include:

  • Oral ulcers - superficial, transient, and often asymptomatic
  • Circinate balanitis - consists of vesicles that rupture to form painless superficial erosions on the glans penis

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with altered mental status. Lab workup shows serum sodium of 110 mEq/L and negative alcohol and toxicology screens. An opacity in the left lower lung is seen on the chest X-Ray. What is the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) with altered mental status, and the management in this patient is 3% saline.

SIADH occurs due to excessive production of ADH (or vasopressin). The most common cause are neuroendocrine neoplasms like small cell lung carcinoma (at least half the cases) and carcinoids.

Symptoms include decreased thirst, lethargy, nausea, confusion, depressed mental status, and seizures. However, most patients are asymptomatic and are diagnosed incidentally due to the presence of hyponatremia. The severity of symptoms indicates the severity of hyponatremia. Hyponatremia occurs with decreased serum osmolality and normal or increased urine osmolality.

Management includes correction of hyponatremia and treatment of the underlying malignancy. Since hyponatremia develops over several weeks to months, it should be corrected gradually at a rate of 0.5–1 meq/L/h to prevent brain dehydration and central pontine myelinolysis (an acute life-threatening neurological syndrome characterized by quadriparesis, ataxia, and abnormal extraocular movements).

  • Hypervolemic hyponatremia:
    • Fluid restriction to less than urine output, plus insensible losses, with strict monitoring of fluid intake in mild cases
    • Vasopressin receptor antagonists, like conivaptan and tolvaptan, in severe cases
  • Hypovolemic hyponatremia and/or altered mental status (indicating severe hyponatremia of <115 mEq/L): Hypertonic (3%) or isotonic saline infusion

Demeclocycline, an inhibitor of vasopressin, is not preferred due to its relatively slower onset of action (1–2 weeks).

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of ischemic heart disease presents with palpitations for the last 3 days. A transesophageal echo shows a thrombus in the left atrium. His ECG is shown below. Which of the following should be done to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with ECG showing  irregular RR intervals with absent P waves is suggestive of atrial fibrillation. His CHA2DS2-VASc score is 2 (history of ischemic heart disease and age of 70), he is symptomatic for > 48 hours, and there is presence of a left atrial thrombus thus requiring initiation of anticoagulation.  

The major source of thromboembolism and stroke in AF is the formation of thrombus in the left atrial appendage due to stagnant flow. Hence thromboembolism must be prevented by giving anticoagulants, along with an appropriate rate/rhythm control strategy with the help of electrical or pharmacologic cardioversion. 

The treatment of atrial fibrillation depends on three things: the duration of symptoms, the severity of symptoms, and the risk of stroke. The patients who present within 48 hours of the onset of symptoms have a lower risk of an existing atrial thrombus and can be safely cardioverted. Those who present with unknown or known onset of more than 48 hours should ideally be anticoagulated before cardioversion. This can be done in 2 ways as shown below:

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with incoordination, tremors, and impaired concentration. On examination, the abdomen is distended and the liver is palpable 3 cm below the right costal margin. The ophthalmic examination is shown in the picture.  Which of the following is the gold standard test for the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Wilson's disease with the ophthalmic examination showing a typical sunflower cataract and the gold standard test for the diagnosis of this patient is liver biopsy.

Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder of copper transport, primarily affecting the liver and brain (hence, it is also known as hepatolenticular disease). It occurs due to a loss-of-function mutation in the ATP7B gene. This gene encodes ATP7B, a copper-transporting ATPase, which is responsible for biliary copper excretion and incorporation of copper into ceruloplasmin.

Clinical features of Wilson's disease are:

  • Hepatic: Hepatomegaly, jaundice, ascites, cirrhosis, anorexia
  • Neurologic: Dystonia, dysarthria, dysphagia, rigidity, tremors, abnormal gait, uncoordinated handwriting
  • Psychiatric: Decreased scholastic performance, irritability, depression, and anxiety
  • Ophthalmic:
    • Kayser-Fleischer rings: These are golden-brown rings formed due to the deposition of copper in descemet’s membrane of the cornea. They are present in 95% of patients with neurologic/psychiatric symptoms and 65% of patients with hepatic symptoms.
    • Sunflower cataracts: These are formed due to the deposition of copper in the lens.
  • Autonomic: Orthostatic hypotension; sweating; bowel, bladder, and sexual dysfunction
  • Endocrine: Delayed puberty, amenorrhea
  • Hemolytic anemia (due to the release of copper from necrosed hepatocytes into the bloodstream)
  • Osteoporosis and rickets
  • Renal Fanconi syndrome

Laboratory findings show low serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels and elevated hepatic enzymes. Increased urinary excretion of copper (>100 μg/24 h) is also an important diagnostic test. However, percutaneous needle liver biopsy to measure hepatic copper remains the gold standard. Hepatic copper values >200 μg/g of dry weight indicate Wilson’s disease.  DNA testing for mutations in ATP7B can be done and can make a definitive diagnosis in about 50–75% of patients.

Treatment of Wilson's disease includes:

  • Copper chelation:
    • D-penicillamine: It increases urinary excretion of copper and prevents copper overload. Pyridoxine (vitamin B6 ) is administered along with it to counter pyridoxine deficiency that occurs due to penicillamine.
    • Triethylenetetramine dihydrochloride: This chelating agent is given in patients intolerant to D-penicillamine and those with severe neurologic manifestations (D-penicillamine worsens neurological status).
    • Tetrathiomolybdate: This fast-acting agent decreases copper absorption and circulating free copper. It is currently under clinical trials.
  • Zinc acetate: This is used to reduce copper absorption. Zinc is beneficial in pregnancy (lower teratogenic effects) and as a maintenance therapy.
  • Liver transplantation: This is considered in advanced stages of irreversible hepatic damage or poor compliance with medical therapy.

A known type 1 diabetic patient presented to the emergency with abdominal pain, vomiting, and nausea. He reports having missed his insulin dose. DKA is suspected in him. So an ABG is taken and a fluid infusion is started. Insulin administration is not given until ABG reports are available. What could be the possible reason for delaying insulin?

DKA: Diabetic ketoacidosis

ABG: Arterial blood gas analysis

choices.text: Insulin alters the values in ABG analysis

questions.solution:
The given scenario points towards a likely diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) that could be associated with hypokalemia. Insulin causes potassium uptake by activating Na-K+ ATPases which may worsen hypokalemia.

DKA is an acute, severe, hyperglycemic disorder, which was considered a hallmark of type 1 diabetes, but can occur in type 2 diabetes as well. Inadequate administration of insulin (especially during times of physiologic stress like infections) may precipitate DKA.

Features of DKA include:

  • Nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain
  • Hypotension and tachycardia
  • Hyperglycemia, glycosuria, and ketosis
  • High anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA)

As a physiologic response to acidosis, the body loses potassium and there is total body potassium deficit. Serum potassium might be normal or elevated, despite total body potassium deficit.

The initial treatment in DKA is fluid administration (first normal saline, then half-normal saline, then dextrose+ half- normal saline). Insulin has to be given once potassium status is known. If insulin is administered prior to potassium correction, it would worsen the preexisting hypokalemia.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with excruciating pain in her lips, gums, and cheeks for the past 6 months. The pain is usually triggered by talking and brushing her teeth. Each pain episode lasts for 1-2 minutes. On examination, there is no sensory loss over the face. Which of the following is the first-line management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of trigeminal neuralgia. The first-line management of this patient is carbamazepine.

Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition characterized by excruciating paroxysmal pain in the lips, gums, cheek, or chin and, rarely ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. It is also known as tic douloureux (a painful condition of the face). It is commonly seen in middle-aged and elderly women. 

The large myelinated fibers of the trigeminal nerve carry tactile stimuli from the face and do not carry pain fibers themselves. In trigeminal neuralgia, due to compression or other pathologies, the large fibers undergo demyelination. These demyelinated large fibers become hyperexcitable and electrically coupled with the surrounding smaller unmyelinated pain fibers of the trigeminal nerve. This explains why tactile stimulation of trigger zones (lips, gums, cheek, or chin) leads to pain paroxysms. Symptoms occur due to ectopic generation of action potentials in pain-sensitive afferent fibers of the trigeminal nerve root just before entering the pons.

The pain may occur spontaneously or after movements like chewing, speaking, smiling, washing the face, brushing teeth, or exposure to wind. On examination, the physician will not find any sensory loss over the area. The pain usually lasts for seconds or minutes. The intensity of pain is severe, so much so that the patient winces. Therefore it is called a 'tic'.

Carbamazepine is the first-line drug in the management of patients with trigeminal neuralgia. Lamotrigine, Phenytoin, Topiramate, or Gabapentin are other options that may be tried if Carbamazepine is ineffective. Microvascular decompression of the trigeminal nerve can be done if medical therapies fail.

Differential diagnoses of trigeminal neuralgia include:

  • Migraine and cluster headaches - They tend to have deep-seated and continuous pain while trigeminal neuralgia has more of a superficial stabbing quality pain and is episodic. 
  • Short-lasting unilateral headache with conjunctival tearing (SUNCT) - It will typically present with unilateral conjunctival congestion, tearing, and nasal stuffiness. 
  • Temporal arteritis - It will usually be accompanied by myalgias and signs of systemic inflammation. ESR and CRP will be elevated.
  • If trigeminal neuralgia develops in a young patient or is bilateral, a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis should be considered. In such cases, the cause of the pain is a demyelinating plaque near the entry point of the trigeminal nerve in the pons.

Laboratory reports of a patient revealed an elevated serum potassium level. What is the classical sequence of ECG changes seen in this patient?
  1. Tall peaked T wave
  2. Loss of P wave
  3. Widened QRS complex
  4. Sine wave pattern
questions.solution:
Elevated serum potassium level is called hyperkalemia. The classical sequence of ECG changes seen with increasing severity of hyperkalemia is option B - 1, 2, 3, 4.

Hyperkalemia is defined by serum K+ > 5.5mM. It usually manifests as a medical emergency with cardiac arrhythmias such as sinus bradycardia, sinus arrest, slow idioventricular rhythms, ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation.

Note: These changes are particularly insensitive in patients with CKD.

questions.text: An elderly man presented with a painful and swollen right knee, and difficulty in walking. After examining the knee joint, aspiration is done. The following image is seen on the examination of synovial fluid using compensated polarized microscopy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image of weakly positive birefringent, rhomboid-shaped crystals are suggestive of pseudogout.

Pseudogout is a condition that occurs due to the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals (CPPD). It presents with features similar to acute gout and predominantly affects the elderly. This is attributable to the increased levels of inorganic pyrophosphate in diseased or aging cartilage which promotes CPP crystal nucleation and their deposition.

Acute attacks of CPPD presents with joint swelling and pain, affecting the knee (most common), wrist, shoulders, elbows, and hands. It also has systemic features of inflammation including fever, chills, and elevated CRP. Chronic CPPD commonly presents as polyarticular arthritis resembling osteoarthritis (pseudo-osteoarthritis). It affects atypical joints such as metacarpophalangeal, wrist, elbow, and ankle joints causing severe damage.

X-ray or ultrasonography of the joint shows chondrocalcinosis, which is punctate or linear radiodense deposits in the joint menisci or articular cartilage. Detection of rod-like or rhomboid crystals in synovial fluid or articular cartilage is diagnostic of pseudogout.

Other options :

Option A: Osteoarthritis also affects the elderly. Commonly involved joints are the hip, knee, and first metatarsal phalangeal joint (MTP). The synovial fluid in osteoarthritis is non-inflammatory. If the synovial fluid white blood cell count is >1000/μL, it is likely to be due to inflammatory arthritis, gout, or pseudogout.

Option C: Gouty arthritis is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals (MSU) crystals which are needle-shaped and negatively birefringent. They appear yellowish when observed under polarized light. Below image shows needle-shaped, monosodium urate crystal in gout.

Option D: Psoriatic arthritis usually occurs after the development of skin lesions in a patient with psoriasis. It usually presents with dactylitis (involving the distal interphalangeal joint) and enthesitis. It is diagnosed by X-ray features of pencil-in-cup deformity, marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation (whiskering) and telescoping of digits.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male patient came to the emergency department with fever and severe constrictive chest pain that worsened with deep inspiration and on lying down. He had a myocardial infarction 2 weeks back. A pericardial friction sound was audible at the lower left sternal border. The electrocardiogram is given below.  Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is due to an infection in the pericardium
Aspirin is given as first line treatment
Colchicine can be used in treatment

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a post-myocardial infarction (MI) patient presenting with pleuritic chest pain, fever, malaise, pericardial rub on auscultation, and the ECG given above showing diffuse ST-segment elevation with upward concavity are suggestive of Dressler syndrome.

Dressler syndrome/post-myocardial infarction syndrome is an autoimmune condition (option B) with inflammation of the pericardium. It presents as pleuritic chest pain, fever, malaise, and sometimes a pleuritic rub and effusion. The ECG findings include PR segment depression or ST-segment elevation. It commonly occurs 1–8 weeks after MI (option A). However, it can recur over months.

Treatment:

  • First-line therapy consists of aspirin 650 mg (option C) every 4 hours with NSAIDs like Ibuprofen or Indomethacin
  • Colchicine (option D) enhances the response to NSAIDs and prevents recurrence
  • Glucocorticosteroids and NSAIDs are best avoided in patients with Dressler syndrome within 4 weeks of STEMI as they may impair infarct healing, cause ventricular rupture, and increase coronary vascular resistance

Complications of myocardial infarction:

  • Myocardial rupture
  • Contractile dysfunction
  • Arrhythmia: Ventricular fibrillation is the most common arrhythmia within one hour of MI
  • Supraventricular tachycardia
  • Heart block
  • Pericarditis: occur even 48 hours after MI
  • Dressler syndrome or post-MI syndrome: 2-3 weeks after a transmural MI
  • Ventricular aneurysm
  • Progressive late heart failure (chronic IHD)
  • Infarct expansion associated with mural thrombus
  • Papillary muscle dysfunction

Myocardial rupture: Various forms of cardiac rupture typically occur when there is transmural necrosis of a ventricle. 

Rupture of the left ventricular free wall
  • Most common
  • 3-7 days after MI
  • Hemopericardium and cardiac tamponade
Rupture of the ventricular septum
  • Less common
  • Acute ventricular septal defect (VSD) and left-to-right shunting
Papillary muscle rupture
  • Least common
  • Severe mitral regurgitation

questions.text: A female patient presented to the emergency room with right-sided flank pain radiating to the groin for 1 day. Urinalysis shows crystals, as seen below. What are these crystals made up of?
questions.solution:
Dumbbell-shaped and envelope-shaped crystals in this patient are indicative of calcium oxalate stones.

The classic presentation for a patient with nephrolithiasis (renal calculi) is acute renal colic, which is the sudden onset of severe pain originating in the flank and radiating inferiorly and anteriorly (loin to groin). It is usually accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and hematuria. Urinalysis showing dumbbell and envelope-shaped crystals confirm that the kidney stones are made up of calcium oxalate. 

Risk factors for calcium oxalate stones:

  • Hyperparathyroidism (Causes hypercalcemia)
  • Hypercalciuria with normal serum calcium:
    • Hyperabsorption of calcium from the intestine (absorptive hypercalciuria)
    • Intrinsic impairment in renal tubular reabsorption of calcium (renal hypercalciuria)
    • Idiopathic fasting hypercalciuria with normal parathyroid function
  • Hyperoxaluria: Hereditary or acquired (intestinal malabsorption syndromes or excess intake of oxalate)
  • Hyperuricosuria
  • Hypocitraturia: Due to idiopathic causes, acidosis or chronic diarrhea.

There are four main types of calculi

  • Calcium stones (most common): composed of calcium oxalate or calcium oxalate mixed with calcium phosphate
  • Triple stones or struvite stones: composed of magnesium ammonium phosphate
  • Uric acid stones 
  • Cystine
