questions.text:
A male patient came with complaints of fatigue, weakness, and irritability for a few weeks. He was on antitubercular drugs for the past 1 month. The laboratory investigations are given below. The most likely diagnosis is :
  • Hemoglobin - Reduced
  • Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) - Reduced
  • Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) - Raised
  • Serum ferritin - Raised
  • Serum iron - Raised
  • Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) - Normal
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is sideroblastic anemia. 

The following are the points given in the question pointing to this diagnosis: 

  • Symptoms of anemia - fatigue, weakness
  • History of taking anti-tubercular drugs (isoniazid)
  • Laboratory investigations showing - reduced MCH, raised MCV, raised serum iron, raised serum ferritin, and normal TIBC 

Isoniazid has a pyridoxine antagonistic action, which results in defective heme synthesis. Pyridoxine acts as a cofactor of the aminolevulinic acid (ALA) synthetase enzyme, which is the rate-limiting enzyme in heme synthesis. Isoniazid-induced sideroblastic anemia is a rare condition due to defective heme synthesis.

Sideroblastic anemia is a group of disorders characterized by the presence of sideroblasts. Sideroblasts are nucleated red cells (normoblasts) containing non-heme siderotic granules and stain Prussian blue positive. Based on etiology, sideroblastic anemia is classified into hereditary and acquired types.

Hereditary sideroblastic anemia: 

It is an X-linked disorder caused by a defect in the activity of ALA synthetase required for heme synthesis. Affected females act as carriers, but males have moderate to marked anemia, which manifests in childhood or early adulthood.

Acquired sideroblastic anemia: This is further divided into - 

1) Primary acquired/idiopathic/refractory - it is regarded as a myelodysplastic disorder in the FAB classification. It occurs in middle-aged and elderly individuals of both sexes. This occurs due to the reduced activity of the ALA synthetase enzyme. This furthermore causes disturbed growth and maturation of the erythroid precursors (hematopoietic stem cells). Anaemia is moderate to severe and appears gradually.

2) Secondary Acquired - may occur secondary to - 

  • Drugs, chemicals, and toxins - isoniazid, alcohol, and lead
  • Hematological disorders - myelofibrosis, acute leukemia, lymphoma, and hemolytic anemia.
  • Miscellaneous - inflammatory diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus.

Peripheral smear in sideroblastic anemia shows hypochromic microcytic (sometimes normocytic) anemia. MCH and MCV are reduced in the hereditary type and raised in the acquired type. Serum ferritin and serum iron are raised, and TIBC shows complete saturation. Bone marrow examination shows erythroid hyperplasia with pathognomonic ring sideroblasts, as shown below.

Pyridoxine for 2-3 months is administered routinely to all cases of sideroblastic anemia. Blood transfusion and other supportive therapy may be required. In cases of secondary sideroblastic anemia, the primary focus is the removal of the offending agent.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic patient with COVID-19 who was on invasive ventilation was given 40 mg of methylprednisolone for 7 days. After recovery, he developed facial pain and swelling. The tissue obtained from the sinuses showed the following finding.  If amphotericin B is not available, which other drug can be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing ribbon-like, irregular, aseptate hyphae is suggestive of mucormycosis. Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the first line of treatment. If Amphotericin B is not available, isavuconazole can be given to this patient.

Mucormycosis is a group of highly invasive, progressive, even life-threatening infections caused by fungi of the order Mucorales. Important fungi are rhizopus, mucor, actinomucor, etc.

These mucorales are present almost everywhere in the environment and humans are constantly exposed. But, infection is usually seen in immunocompromised states such as diabetes mellitus, glucocorticoid treatment, solid organ or hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) and prolonged neutropenia. Recently, there was a rise in incidence of mucormycosis (which was alredy hyper-endemic in india) during the Covid 19 pandemic. 

It can presentin five forms: Rhino-orbital-cerebral, pulmonary, cutaneous, gastrointestinal, or disseminated disease. Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis is the most common form. The initial presentation is nonspecific with eye or facial pain and facial numbness followed by conjunctival suffusion and dimunition of vision. If untreated it can spread from the sinuses to the orbit, and to the frontal lobe, and may also cause cavernous sinus thrombosis. On examination, sinuses may look normal in initial stages, and may need blind bipsy. In later stages, there is erythema (with or without edema), followed by a necrotic eschar.

Diagnosis is made by culturing the organisms from the sterile sites like needle aspirate, pleural fluid, or a tissue biopsy specimen. The biopsy is most sensitive. It reveals characteristic wide, thick-walled, ribbon-like, aseptate hyphal elements that branch at right angles.

Management:

  • Amphotericin B is the first line, antifungal agent. The dose of liposomal amphotericin formulation is 5-10mg/kg/day. Other antifungal agents used are isavuconazole and posaconazole
  • Treatment of the underlying risk factors
  • Surgical debridement

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus for the first time. When should he visit an ophthalmologist?

choices.text: When symptoms of loss of vision begin to appear

questions.solution:
A patient with type II diabetes mellitus should visit the ophthalmologist at the time of diagnosis of diabetes. 

American Diabetes Association recommends: 

  • For type 2 diabetes mellitus - immediate comprehensive eye examination just after the diagnosis of diabetes 
  • For type 1 diabetes mellitus - comprehensive eye examination within 5 years of diabetes onset.
  • For women with preexisting type 1 or type 2 diabetes who become pregnant or are planning pregnancy - comprehensive eye examination before pregnancy or in the first trimester. Furthermore, these patients should be monitored every trimester and for 1 year postpartum.

After the initial examination in both type 1 and type 2 DM,

  • Annual examination of fundus is recommended therafter.
  • If there is no significant abnormality, the fundus should be examined every 2 years.
Severe vision loss is a microvascular complication of DM primarily due to progressive diabetic retinopathy, characterised by macular edema and new blood vessel formation. Diabetic retinopathy is classified into two stages:
  • Nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy : Usually presents in the 1st decade of hyperglycemia
  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy

The most effective therapy for diabetic retinopathy is prevention. Hence, intensive glycemic and blood pressure control and routine screening becomes essential. 

Related Pearl: Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study (ETDRS) classification

Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR):

  • Mild NPDR
    • At least one microaneurysm must be present
  • Moderate NPDR
    • Microaneurysms/intraretinal hemorrhage in 2 or 3 quadrants
    • Early mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)
    • Hard exudates and cotton-wool spots may or may not be present
  • Severe NPDR - any one of the following (4-2-1 rule)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes
  • Very severe NPDR - any two of the following (4-2-1)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR):

  • PDR without high-risk characteristics (Early PDR)
    • Early neovascularization at the optic disc (NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere (NVE)
  • PDR with high-risk characteristics as follows
    • NVD < 1/4 disc area with vitreous hemorrhage (VH) or preretinal hemorrhage (PRH)
    • NVD 1/4 to 1/3 of disc area with or without VH or PRH
    • NVE > 1/2 disc area with VH or PRH

Clinically significant macular edema: 1 of the following 3 criteria are present on slit-lamp examination with 90D lens

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 micron of the center of the fovea.
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 micron of the centre of fovea associated with adjacent retinal thickening.

questions.text: A young boy from Africa comes with complains of fever, night sweats and a swelling over the jaw. On biopsy of the lesion, histopathology showed a starry sky appearance. Cytogenetics revealed a t (8;14) translocation. What is the likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the biopsy findings of starry sky appearance and cytogenetics showing t(8;14) translocation point to a likely diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma. 

Burkitt's lymphoma is a type of non-hodgkin's lymphoma. It arises from mature germinal center B-cells that express surface IgM, CD19, CD20, CD10, and BCL6. It is one of the fastest growing tumors, with a high doubling time.

It can occur in 3 forms mainly preseting in children or young adults:

  • African (endemic) Burkitt lymphoma - it often presents as a mass involving the mandible. It may also involve the abdominal viscera, particularly the kidneys, ovaries, and adrenal glands. 
  • Sporadic (non-endemic) Burkitt lymphoma - it most often appears as a mass involving the ileocecum and peritoneum
  • Aggressive lymphoma or acute leukemia - it is seen in immunocompromised individuals

All forms of Burkitt lymphoma are associated with increased MYC protein levels due to translocations of the MYC gene on chromosome 8. Depending in the translocation partner common chromosomal abnormalities are:

  • t (8;14) causing MYC-IGH fusion - most common 
  • t (8;22) causing MYC-Kappa fusion
  • t (2;8) causing MYC-Lambda fusion

The tumor shows a high mitotic index with numerous apoptotic cells. The nuclear remnants of these apoptotic cells are phagocytosed by interspersed benign macrophages. The phagocytes have abundant clear cytoplasm, creating a characteristic starry sky pattern.

Despite being an aggressive tumor, it responds well to intensive chemotherapy. Chemotherapy with EPOCH-R (rituximab, infusional etoposide/vincristine/doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, prednisone) is highly effective.

Which among these pairs are the correctly matched conditions with their mode of inheritance?
  1. Factor V deficiency - X-linked recessive
  2. Factor VII deficiency - Autosomal recessive
  3. Factor VIII deficiency - X-linked recessive
  4. Factor IX deficiency - X-linked recessive
  5. Factor X deficiency - Autosomal dominant
questions.solution:
The correctly matched conditions with their mode of inheritance are 2, 3, and 4.

Factors VIII and IX deficiencies are inherited as X-linked recessive traits, whereas factors V, VII, and X deficiencies are inherited as autosomal recessive traits.

Factors VIII and IX deficiencies are also known as hemophilia A and B, respectively.

Clinically, hemophilia A and B are indistinguishable. Mild disease usually presents as bleeding following major trauma. Moderate to severe disease presents as bleeding into the joints (hemarthrosis), soft tissues, and muscles after minor trauma or spontaneously.

These patients usually have a normal bleeding time and platelet counts. The diagnosis can be made only after specific determination of FVIII or FIX clotting activity.

Factor replacement therapy is the treatment of choice either after a bleeding episode or prophylactically.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient with a history of fatiguability, weight gain, cold intolerance, and thick, dry skin for the last 6 months. He was brought to the casualty with reduced consciousness level, hypothermia, bradycardia, and hypotension and a recent history of pneumonia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history suggests of a typical case of hypothyroidism, and the likely diagnosis is myxedema coma.

Myxedema coma is a severe neurological complication of hypothyroidism. It is mostly seen in the elderly and has a high mortality rate of 20-40%. It is often precipitated by:

  • Drugs like sedatives, antidepressants, anaesthetics
  • Infections like pneumonia
  • Congestive heart failure, myocardial ischemia
  • Cerebrovascular accidents
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding
  • Exposure to cold

All these cause hypoventilation, leading to hypoxia and hypercapnia. 

Clinical features include a reduced level of consciousness, seizures, hypothermia (can reach 23°C), metabolic disturbances, and symptoms and signs of hypothyroidism (fatiguability, cold intolerance, thick dry skin, weight gain, constipation, etc).

Management of myxedema coma involves:

  • Pharmacotherapy:
    • Levothyroxine (T4): Single loading IV dose (200-400 mcg) and maintenance oral dose (1.6 mcg/kg/day)
    • Liothyronine (T3): Added along with T4 either via nasogastric tube or IV 
    • Parenteral hydrocortisone (50 mg every 6 h): Given to correct the impaired levels of corticoid hormones
    • Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics: Given in case of infections
  • Supportive therapy:
    • Hypertonic saline or IV glucose if severe hyponatremia or hypoglycemia is present
    • External warming if body temperature is <30° to prevent circulatory collapse and use of space blankets to prevent heat loss
    • Ventilatory support with regular blood-gas analysis in the first 48 h
    • Avoidance of hypotonic fluids to prevent fluid retention

Other options:

Option A: Septic shock occurs due to systemic infections like bacterial and fungal infections, toxic shock syndrome, pancreatitis etc, massive trauma, and severe burns, resulting in fatal organ failure. Massive release of inflammatory cytokines causes peripheral vasodilation and pooling, which causes the skin to look flushed. Vascular damage, DIC, and alveolar damage (shock lung) can be seen.

Option B: Cardiogenic shock occurs due to myocardial pump failure, resulting in low cardiac output. It is associated with conditions like myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, cardiac tamponade, and pulmonary embolism. Patients present with hypotension, a weak rapid pulse, tachypnea, and cool clammy skin.

Option D: Hypoglycemia occurs due to insulin or insulin-producing drugs used to treat diabetes mellitus or other substances like alcohol. It is characterised by low plasma glucose levels and relief of symptoms after normalization of plasma glucose levels. Along with neurological symptoms (behavioural changes, confusion, fatigue, seizures, loss of consciousness), adrenergic symptoms (palpitations, tremors, anxiety), cholinergic symptoms (sweating, hunger), and diaphoresis are present. Increased heart rate and BP are mainly seen in individuals with repeated episodes.

questions.text: A patient with a known history of peptic ulcers comes with hematemesis. The urea breath test is positive. The patient's gastric biopsy is taken, and the slide is shown below. The patient is at the highest risk of developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and gastric biopsy showing curved bacteria filling the lumen of a gastric foveola is indicative of Helicobacter pylori infection. This patient is at the highest risk of developing gastric adenocarcinoma.

H. pylori is a gram-negative bacillus that lives in gastric mucus and duodenum. It is acid-resistant and motile due to its spiral shape and flagella.

H. pylori is a known risk factor for peptic ulcer disease, gastritis, gastric adenocarcinoma, and gastric lymphoma. However, the risk of developing gastric adenocarcinoma is much more than the risk of developing gastric lymphoma.

Many studies have shown H. pylori is protective against peptic esophageal diseases, including esophageal adenocarcinoma and GERD. It is due to H. pylori-induced hypochlorhydria. 

Diagnosis of H. pylori is by:

  • Tests based on endoscopic biopsy - biopsy urease test, histology, and culture of the biopsy specimen.
  • Non-invasive tests - 13C Urea breath test and stool antigen test is useful for follow-up after treatment. H. pylori contains an enzyme called urease. It splits urea into carbon dioxide and ammonium ions. In urea breath test, 13C is ingested by the patient. If H. pylori is present, the urease activity generates 13C-labeled CO2 that then can be detected in the patient’s exhaled breath.

The given image shows Helicobacter pylori on gastric mucosa stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with sudden onset of pleuritic chest pain, breathlessness, and cramping pain in the right leg. He reports to have had deep vein thrombosis in the right leg 1 year ago. His BP was 128/88 mmHg and his pulse was 110 bpm. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pulmonary embolism (PE). The investigation of choice for the diagnosis of this condition is CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA).

PE and deep vein thrombosis (DVT) are part of the same spectrum of venous thromboembolism. PE occurs due to obstruction of the pulmonary arterial circulation by deep venous thrombi that detach from their site of formation and embolize to the vena cava, right atrium, and right ventricle.

Virchow’s triad of venous stasis, hypercoagulability, and endothelial injury, leading to recruitment of activated platelets, provides the ideal environment for thrombus formation.

PE can be classified as:

  • High-risk massive PE (extensive thrombosis affecting at least half of the pulmonary vasculature): Characterised by dyspnea, syncope, hypotension, cyanosis, cardiogenic shock, multisystem organ failure
  • Intermediate-risk submassive PE: Characterised by right ventricular (RV) dysfunction with normal systemic arterial pressure.
  • Low-risk PE: Shows excellent prognosis

Symptoms of PE are nonspecific, the most common among them being unexplained breathlessness.

Well's criteria is used to assess the likelihood of PE in a patient. For a patient with low-to-moderate likelihood of PE, the initial investigation is measurement of D-dimer levels. Whereas, for a patient with high likelihood of PE, the choice of investigation is CTPA. 

In the given patient, clinical signs of DVT, past history of DVT, heart rate >100 bpm, and a diagnosis other than PE being less likely contribute to the high likelihood of PE according to Well's criteria.

A normal D-dimer test helps to rule out PE. However, increased D-dimer levels are nonspecific as they can be seen in patients with other systemic illnesses including myocardial infarction (MI), pneumonia, sepsis, and cancer.

CTPA, also known as CT chest angiogram with contrast, is performed in patients with high probability of PE or those with low-to-moderate probability but elevated D-dimer levels. It is highly specific and sensitive, and a positive CTPA showing a filling defect confirms the diagnosis of PE.

The arrows in the image below show a large pulmonary embolism at the bifurcation of the pulmonary artery (saddle embolism):

Other options:

Option A: Echocardiography is not reliable because most patients with PE have normal echocardiograms. However, it can be used for detecting conditions that mimic PE like acute MI, pericardial tamponade, and aortic dissection. The best indirect sign of PE on transthoracic echo is McConnell’s sign (hypokinesis of the RV free wall with normal or hyperkinetic motion of the RV apex).

Option C: Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scanning is a second-line diagnostic test that detects absent or decreased blood flow due to PE. It is performed when CTPA is contraindicated or inconclusive and additional testing is required.

Option D: MR pulmonary angiography may detect large proximal PE but is not reliable for smaller segmental and subsegmental PE.

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Venous Thromboembolism

The risk factors for venous thromboembolism (pulmonary embolism and DVT) are as follows:

  • Major trauma like spinal cord injury or fracture of lower limb
  • Surgery like hip or knee replacement
  • Hospitalization for heart failure or atrial fibrillation/flutter within last 3 months
  • Myocardial infarction within last 3 months
  • Previous venous thromboembolism
  • Infections and inflammatory bowel disease

    • Pregnancy and postpartum period
    • COPD
    • Nephrotic syndrome
    • Polycythemia vera
    • Malignancies

  • Prolonged car or air travel.

questions.text: A  patient comes with complaints of fever, cough with foul-smelling sputum, and night sweats. She reported having undergone a tooth extraction a few days ago. On examination, clubbing is seen and cavernous breath sounds are heard over the right lung.  Her chest X-ray is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diganosis is lung abscess. 

The clinical points in the question pointing to this diagnosis are: 

  • History of fever, cough with foul-smelling discharge and night sweats
  • History of tooth extraction pointing towards the possibility of aspiration
  • Clubbing and cavernous breath sounds are heard over the right lung
  • Chest X-ray image showing a thick-walled cavity with air-fluid level

Lung abscess represents necrosis and cavitation of the lung following microbial infection. They are broadly divided into two categories:

  • Primary lung abscess usually occurs in the abscence of any underlying systemic or pulmonary condition. They usually occur in the posterior upper lobes and superior lower lobes of the lungs. The right lung is more commonly involved because of less angulated right mainstem bronchus. They are polymicrobial in nature including anaerobes and microaerophilic streptococci. Aspiration is a major risk factor (hence alcoholic patients are at higher risk).
  • Secondary lung abscess usually occurs in the presence of an underlying lung or systemic condition. The location of the abscess varies with the underlying condition. Generally they occur due to a broad bacterial spectrum including Pseudomonas aeruginosa and other gram-negative rods.

Clinical features include fever, night sweats, productive cough with foul-smelling sputum, and chest pain. 

Physical examination usually reveals poor dentition/gingival disease, digital clubbing, and absence of a gag reflex. Amphoric and/or cavernous breath sounds can be heard during auscultation.

Chest X-ray features of lung abscess:

  • A lung cavity with an air-fluid level
  • Thick and irregular cavity wall and a surrounding pulmonary-infiltrate

Computed tomography (CT) is more sensitive than chest radiography and is used to detect small cavities.

Clindamycin, or amoxicillin-clavulanate, or moxifloxacin can be administered for primary lung abscesses. Antibiotics for secondary lung abscesses are prescribed according to the pathogen identified. The treatment is usually prolonged until the resolution of the abscess is achieved.
